title: Remote memory disclosure vulnerability in libcurl on 64 Bit Windows

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

activities.message:
Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!

> An attacker capable of choosing the file to upload may choose for it to be 4294967295 in size

An attacker that can choose the size, can just choose a size that is larger than the buffer in memory (either heap or stack) as then curl will read beyond that provided buffer and upload that data as well. You don't even need to use that buffer-wrap mistake to accomplish this - if you can change the size.

However, I don't think this is a flaw that libcurl can protect itself against!
No worries, hope this is useful. And thank you so much for all your work on curl!

In this case, the size is correct though: I'm assuming a case where the file is indeed 4GB large and the program wants to transmit that. I'm choosing the size to be correct, and still, libcurl transmits more data.
Note also, that it only does that on Windows, and on Linux, the behavior is correct.
oh right yes that's true... btw, where did you see "the documentation states that it MAY NOT contain zero bytes" ? it's not true.
Apologies, that was the NAME field. You are right, the buffer may contain null bytes, it doesn't have to though.

So, okay, if an attacker can trick a program running on 64 bit windows to set `CURLFORM_BUFFERLENGTH` to 4294967295 **and** that 4GB buffer is totally free of nul bytes, libcurl would read beyond the end of that buffer when it sends data...

Yes, exactly. I think the most plausible case is that where an attacker is allowed to specify a file they want transmitted, in which case they can choose one that's null-byte free. With libraries and standard tools like curl, it's hard to tell how they have been integrated into larger systems, of course, so, estimating the impact is hard. Nonetheless, it seems to me that his behavior of ignoring the size and instead using `strlen` is a bug and unexpected behavior, especially because this is only the case on Windows but not on Linux. If the file does include zero bytes, we end up with a truncated file.

This flaw doesn't exist when you use the curl_mime API,  only with curl_formadd() which has been documented as deprecated since Sep 2017. As far as I have seen at least.

> the most plausible case is that where an attacker is allowed to specify a file they want transmitted

That's not a very plausible scenario really (but of course not impossible), because the normal API to transmit a file with a multipart formpost is not to use the buffer option but instead use the CURLFORM_FILE one. The buffer option is for when the application uses an internal buffer instead of an external file, and that is then rarely populated by a user's arbitrary choice of content.

I would find it very odd to find an application what would just allow a user to select a file that would result in a 4GB buffer to be allocated and used.

> ignoring the size and instead using strlen is a bug

I would say that the bug is rather the use of 'long' and the associated overflow when it should use a 'size_t' (but we can't change type since that's part of the ABI). The use of a magic constant to mean strlen() is clearly documented.

The magic constant is defined as
```
#define CURL_ZERO_TERMINATED ((size_t) -1)
```
which, on 64 bit is 18446744073709551615. What happens here is that on Windows, you pass is 4294967295 and it treats it as 18446744073709551615, while on Linux, it correctly treats it as 4294967295.
Yes, because of the stupid unchecked typecast.
Seems very reasonable given the constraints imposed by the ABI.

It seems this bug was added in https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/131645dc310a

Released in curl 7.9.8, release date **June 13th, 2002** - if my [research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/64-bit_computing) is right, the first "real" 64 bit Windows was "Windows XP Professional x64 Edition" released on April 30 2005!

Thinking about it further, I think the most likely way an application can get hurt by this flaw is like this:

The application sends something to a server using curl_formadd() with data stored in a super huge buffer in memory (>4GB). The size of the data in each particular case can differ depending on what it wants to send (meaning it isn't easy to spot the problem). If that size happens to become exactly 4294967295 bytes (and there's no a single nul-byte in the data), the application risks sending off more data than it intended (or crash).

It is probably a security flaw even if that size is **not** set by an attacker. If it **is** set by an attacker, it is way worse.

True, yes: if the buffer is 4294967295, then the program may just expose memory contents to the server. Incredible that it goes back all the way to a commit before Windows 64 bit. I wish I had known about this flaw back in 2016 when we were writing this paper on the kinds of vulnerabilities that pop up when code that worked perfectly fine on 32 bit is ported to 64 bit: https://www.sec.cs.tu-bs.de/pubs/2016-ccs.pdf - this would have been a great example. I guess 20 years ago, people didn't have to worry too much about 4GB buffers considering that the whole address space was 4GB. And for this flaw, even if one does consider a 64 bit platform, the fact that sizeof(long) differs between Windows and Linux is bound to cause trouble.

A related detail that might change how we view this flaw: the `CURLFORM_BUFFERLENGTH` is documented to accept a 'long' that "gives the length of the buffer".

On a windows 64 bit machine, a long that sets "a size of a buffer" cannot contain a value larger than 2^31 (2147483648).

I suppose someone could argue that a reader of this might interpret the text to mean that **the size** of the argument should be the size of a long and thus also an unsigned long should be fine. (I would consider that a stretch.)

The question is then if this flaw requires that you're actually passing in a value that is larger than what it is documented to accept. And if it does, does it change how we view it?

Because this function argument is documented to accept a **long**, I don't think we should consider it a security problem when the application passes in something else. This being a vararg of course explains why the compiler doesn't complain and that's unfortunate. I also think that the function should detect and abort as my proposed patched.

The API only guarantees the documented (secure) functionality when used as documented.

Well, it makes me wonder why it is a signed `long` if it can only be a buffer size according to the documentation and why -1 is treated as CURL_ZERO_TERMINATED, and finally, why a read outside the bounds of a buffer can be triggered here and the bytes so read end up being transmitted to a server. Your call though.

> it makes me wonder why it is a signed long

The answer is simply: bad API construction sense when we made `curl_formadd()` back in 2001. Partly of course because we made it a vararg thing and back then we didn't even normally have 64 bit size_ts. And again: we have also replaced this API with one that doesn't suffer from this restriction.

> why -1 is treated as CURL_ZERO_TERMINATED

I don't think that is a problem in itself, but only in combination with this typecast flaw.

> why a read outside the bounds of a buffer can be triggered here

You know why. Because you pass in a value that gets that effect due to a bug. But you're not passing in a 'long' and therefore you're not following the API as documented.

Ok, so, to summarize: you're saying that while the API allows passing in a long, the documentation clearly states that this long must represent the size of the buffer, and the user should be smart enough not to pass in a negative number although the function allows it. If they do pass in -1, then they can't have any expectations about what libcurl does: since it's not documented what happens in that case is not defined, so, reading until a NULL byte is reached and then sending that over is as good a behavior as any other.

That's a valid perspective to take. You can say: the user of the library just didn't behave as they should have, however, from an attacker's point of view, it really doesn't matter: what they see is that rather than libcurl simply discarding -1 as an invalid buffer size, passing in -1 allows them to transform an incorrect buffer size into an information leak - and this primitive exists in libcurl. OpenSSL, in the last years, has done the right thing for such cases, and handled such inputs gracefully to remove such opportunities and it seems wise to do the same here, especially given that this is an invalid condition (negative buffer size) that libcurl can easily detect.

Those are my two cents on the issue, however, I do not really mind whether you believe this is a vulnerability or not or for that matter, whether I am awarded a bounty. This interaction has been very helpful to me. Thank you. Please feel free to close the issue.

> the documentation clearly states that this long must represent the size of the buffer, and the user should be smart enough not to pass in a negative number

Yes. We can only promise a delivered outcome if the API is used as documented. A negative buffer size is not possible.

> from an attacker's point of view, it really doesn't matter

This is not an argument about what attackers think. For an attacker it doesn't matter who does what and who's right or not as long as they can get the desired effect. We as a security team for libcurl cannot work like that though. We need to care about if this specific  flaw as reported and understood is a security vulnerability in libcurl.

An application that can pass in a negative value in a long as a buffer size to this libcurl function call is an application with a bug. The combination is indeed unfortunate but I don't think that is reason enough for us to mark this as a security problem **in libcurl**.

Luckily, I doubt there actually exists an application out there that does this.
Continued as a PR => https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/8272
